Applied tools such as Python, Pandas, Excel, SQL, and Tableau. A link to a list of my projects and a description of each is provided in the title of this role.

Transformed traditional didactic sequences into engaging content, featuring diverse mediums like infographics, interactives and videos. Employed active teaching techniques to simplify complex topics, fostering a holistic student-centric learning environment.

Conducted Mathematical Quality Assurance, ensuring error-free content through meticulous reviews. Proactively engaged with authors for collaborative problem resolution and assisted in resource creation. As Translation Liaison, facilitated seamless communication between teams. Ensured final resource integrity through comprehensive English and Spanish verification, emphasizing functionality and adherence to the author's intent.

research.summary: Yanag-isawa proved that in non-color tasks, anonymity does not reduce the power of the asynchronous shared memory model. We propose two anonymous models in which it is possible to express more general tasks and we propose an anonymous implementation of immediate snapshots that allow us to use topology for study.

research.topic: Topological Methods in Distributed Computing: Optimal Concurrency and Directed Geometric Semantics
research.summary: Optimal Concurrency and Directed Geometric Semantics Based on Gramoli, Kuznetsov and Ravi’s paper ”In the Search for Optimal Concurrency” [Structural Information and Communication Complexity. SIROCCO 2016. Lecture Notes in Computer Science, vol 9988. Springer, Cham], we are trying to search for the geometrical interpretation (in Directed Semantics) for LS-Linearizable correctness notion and to see if is possible to measure and compare two implementations using distinct synchronization techniques within this interpretation.

I got a new result on Geometry of Efficient Fair Division. We can divide a cake without all absolutely continuous measures into O(n2) cakes with all measures absolutely continuous respect to the other measures.

We studied generalizations of the following problem: we want to divide the plane into several convex components which we call “pens”. We know that at some point someone will destroy all the pens that intersect a straight line. Which is the configuration with fewer pens which ensures that remain 2 without destroying?

We developed a library in C++ which provides fast and easy iterators to a few combinatorial objects. Some of the objects in the library are: Multisets, Subsets, Permutations, Combinations, Partitions, Catalan Paths, Motzkin Paths, etc.
